subject: Ethics
title: Warren and Brandeis: The Right to Be Let Alone
description: A quick win: understand Warren and Brandeis: The Right to Be Let Alone.

hook.text: In 1890, a Boston lawyer was furious. Newspapers kept publishing gossip about his wife's dinner parties.

buildup.text: Samuel Warren teamed up with Louis Brandeis to write a Harvard Law Review article that changed everything.

discovery.text: They argued for a new legal right: 'the right to be let alone.' No law had framed privacy this way.

twist.text: Their trigger wasn't state spying â€” just nosy journalists. The smallest intrusion inspired the biggest idea.

climax.text: That single essay became the foundation for privacy law across the entire Western world.

punchline.text: Modern privacy law started with a dinner party.

quiz.question: What prompted Warren and Brandeis to write their famous privacy essay?
options: Newspaper gossip about private social events
A Supreme Court ruling on free speech
